pull_request.title: [Moco] Add support for the Bordalba et al. (2023) projection method for kinematic constraints
pull_request.body: Fixes issue #3528 ## (Not so) brief summary of changes ### Overview Implemented the "projection" method for enforcing kinematic constraint from [the Bordalba et al. (2023) publication](https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12908). This approach adds two additional sets of variables: 1) a set of auxiliary state variables (that we'll call "projection" states here, to not get confused with auxiliary variables for muscles) and 2) a set of slack variables used to compute the state projection. The projection is enforced by the following equation where `x^prime` are the projection states and `mu` are the slack variables. `F` is the vector of equations representing the holonomic and non-holonomic kinematic constraints in the system, and `F_x` is a matrix representing the partial derivative of these equations with respect to the model states. This method works by enforcing the above equation and replacing the regular (non-prime) states in the defect constraints with the projection states. ### Computing the projection vector Rather than try to reimplement exactly how the original publication computes `F_x`, I instead borrow an idea from Simbody based on how it performs coordinate projection when assembling models with kinematic constraints. For a given state variable, we only need a matrix whose column space provide a basis of the normal space of the constraint manifold in the system in order to project that state back onto the constraint manifold. Simbody accomplishes by using the constraint matrix `G = [P; V; A]`, which contains acceleration-level errors for all kinematic constraints in the system. Here are the expressions used by Simbody to perform coordinate projection (taken from the [Simbody theory manual](https://simtk.org/docman/view.php/97/1028/SimbodyTheoryManual.pdf)): The matrices `P` and `V` are the acceleration-level errors for the system's holonomic and non-holonomic constraints, respectively. The matrices `W` and `T` are constant, diagonal weighting matrices used to scale the size of the coordinate projection and equations at the top represent the projection algorithm that Simbody uses. The weighting matrices shouldn't be necessary for our implementation, since the `mu` variables can scale the size of the projection during the optimization. And, clearly, the equations here are replaced by the projection equation from Bordalba et al. (2023) which enforced as a path constraint in the problem. ### Testing I've completed ### Looking for feedback on... ### CHANGELOG.md (choose one) - no need to update because... - updated.

Yes, that correct. However, every path is fitted independently, so it would be easy enough for users to remove muscles from the model that they do not want in the fitting process. ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 309 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhhLj6qEtNepjcxJvhw:-NhiEX6v4SGvyQUccbvp:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2d1a6feeb7e5a54105b638c26900c84e0c711bcd/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L309)):*

pull_request.title: `PolynomialPathFitter` and other utilities for `FunctionBasedPath`
pull_request.body: Fixes issue #3390 ### Brief summary of changes This PR introduces `PolynomialPathFitter`, a new utility class for creating `FunctionBasedPath`s by fitting the coefficients of `MultivariatePolynomialFunction`s to path length and moment arm samples taken from a model with geometry-based paths. Given a model, a table of coordinate values, and a set of (optional) user settings, this class automatically samples path lengths and moment arms from the model based on Latin hypercube sampling and determins the polynomial coefficients using a least-squares fit. In addition to the new class, various other smaller changes are included to make everything work: - Added `ModelFactor::replacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths` and `ModOpReplacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths`. - Added `calcTermValues` and `calcTermDerivatives` to `MultivariatePolynomialFunction`. - Added `Object::getProperty(const std::string& name)` and `Object::updProperty(const std::string& name)`. - Added `TypeHelper`s to `Property` for `SimTK::Vec2` types. - Added `SimulationUtilities::appendCoupledCoordinateValues` and `TabOpAppendCoupledCoordinateValues`. - Added `SimulationUtilities::appendCoordinateValueDerivatives` and `TabOpAppendCoordinateValueDerivatives`. - Minor updates to `FunctionBasedPath`. - Other various minor drive-by fixes that I encountered along the way. ### Testing I've completed Added `testPolynomialPathFitter.cpp`. ### Looking for feedback on... Anything and everything. ### CHANGELOG.md (choose one) - updated. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581)

review.body:
Looks great @nickbianco Just a couple clarifications and then it's ready to go :+1: 

> Reviewed 9 of 9 files at r2, all commit messages.
> *[Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-:-NhhNXPh16MZLNzYaLP8:bjual1g)* status: all files reviewed, 8 unresolved discussions (waiting on @nickbianco and @pepbos)

___
*[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 157 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhhKHRG2qHyfBAE4Xe_:-NhhKHRG2qHyfBAE4Xea:b7frj13) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2d1a6feeb7e5a54105b638c26900c84e0c711bcd/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L157)):*
> ```objc
>  *
>  * It is highly recommended to use the files printed to the output directory to
>  * evaluate the quality of the fitted paths. Depending on the quality of the
> ```

Maybe documented else where but a pointer to what files are printed and how to use would be helpful.
___
*[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 190 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhhKaJi1uQJoKN4g37Q:-NhhKaJi1uQJoKN4g37R:bm5xj0d) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2d1a6feeb7e5a54105b638c26900c84e0c711bcd/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L190)):*
> ```objc
>      * the model to contain at least one path object derived from `AbstractPath`
>      * and does not already contain any `FunctionBasedPath` objects. The bounds
>      * for clamped coordinates are obeyed during the fitting process. Locked
> ```

To clarify, is the implication that users can't convert to FunctionBasedPaths one muscle/path at a time? Definitely this is cleaner/easier for book-keeping and they can iteratively add and refit, just confirming supported workflow.
___
*[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 309 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhhLj6qEtNepjcxJvhw:-NhhLj6qEtNepjcxJvhx:bfce9my) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2d1a6feeb7e5a54105b638c26900c84e0c711bcd/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L309)):*
> ```objc
> 
>     /**
>      * The global bounds (in degrees) that determine the minimum and maximum
> ```

Anything to say here about translational coordinates?
___
*[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.cpp` line 2 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhhMd3x76i-RcbC0JXi:-NhhMd3x76i-RcbC0JXj:b-lzlfe3) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2d1a6feeb7e5a54105b638c26900c84e0c711bcd/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.cpp#L2)):*
> ```cpp
> /* -------------------------------------------------------------------------- *
>  *                    OpenSim:  PolynomialPathFitter.h                        *
> ```

.cpp :)
___
*[`OpenSim/Actuators/Test/testPolynomialPathFitter.cpp` line 131 at r2](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhhNJYU0-DVZjgIJcsa:-NhhNJYU0-DVZjgIJcsb:b-hy7ngw) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2d1a6feeb7e5a54105b638c26900c84e0c711bcd/OpenSim/Actuators/Test/testPolynomialPathFitter.cpp#L131)):*
> ```cpp
>         REQUIRE_THROWS_WITH(fitter.run(), Catch::Contains(
>             "Expected 'maximum_polynomial_order' to be at most 9"));
>     }
> ```

Very nicely done/tested @nickbianco

issue.title: Run time error when trying to visualize the sim
issue.body:
Ubuntu 22.04, Python 3.9.15, and opensim 4.4.

I am getting the following errors when I set the visualize=True, it runs when I set the visualize=False.
- `RuntimeError: std::exception in 'SimTK::State & OpenSim::Model::initSystem()': SimTK Exception thrown at VisualizerProtocol.cpp:162:`
  - /home/aurelien/anaconda3/envs/opensim/simbody/libexec/simbody/Final system error was errno=2 (No such file or directory).
  (Required condition 'status == 0' was not met.)
- `RuntimeError: std::exception in 'SimTK::State & OpenSim::Model::initSystem()': std::exception` 

These are the steps I took to create my conda environment

1. conda create -n opensim python=3.9
2. conda activate opensim
3. conda install -c opensim-org opensim=4.4=py39np120

Am I missing an install step to be able to visualize the sim?

comment.body:
Hi, I tested the [the 4.4.1 release](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/releases/tag/4.4.1). After installation, when I called `import opensim`, I got `DLL load failed` error. I could fix it by manually adjusting the OpenSim bin path, `F:\opensim-core-4.4.1-win\bin` instead of the following line. Now, it works. It requires the correct path, the `curFolder` variable in this line refers to the Python installation directory not OpenSim. 
https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/81c2455e13f953b4d83bc988107b60ebc3071889/Bindings/Python/__init__.py#L7

Regarding the visualizer, it still doesn't work. Please see this:

https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/assets/38867713/d50b832a-0ef9-4eb5-9356-731bc640bf2a

Have I forgotten something?

review.body:
> *[Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581)* status: 20 of 29 files reviewed, 10 unresolved discussions (waiting on @aymanhab and @pepbos) *[a discussion](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhXpxVw4HrhIuq3TiGc:-Nhcx6xp-IFocUI4R6j1:bw8isc9) (no related file):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
Thanks for the clarification @nickbianco now I can proceed.
Thanks @aymanhab, ready for review again. ___ ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/ModelFactory.cpp` line 318 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhXzZzO0oex9gnpTi0L:-Nhcnmzv2JzXcMbRL15c:bczphna) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/ModelFactory.cpp#L318)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
Have you considered using Path or AbstractPath instead of Force? If so we use more specific class in updComponent<> here so we don't end up catching unrelated components? I think there're methods to go from Path to the owner component safely and you're only using Object level methods anyway.
The problem is that `AbstractPath`s usually do not have unique names/paths in the model. So I could search through all `AbstractPath`s in the model, but I'd end up having to check the `Force` name anyway. The subsequent line checks if the `path` property exists in the component. ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 46 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhbrrsX-CvPfNnTxd2y:-NhcqPU28zALY4UOlJmr:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L46)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
coordinate may not be "bounded" in the model, would it be clearer to say path to the coordinate to be bounded during fitting?
Done. ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 80 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-Nhbt4BwAZfTTftYngGg:-Nhcqgh29g1HFu7wP8-z:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L80)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
using absolute value?
Done. ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 97 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhbuTfMBiWbqCMulq9z:-NhcrATIBK-e94vUE4Ob:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L97)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
With all these tolerances I'm assuming the model is assumed to be in meters so a model of a small bird or a dinosaur may not work out of the box? Is this something to account for or include a disclaimer?
Done. ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 400 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-Nhbta3dB7jbYDgFTgff:-NhcsRsu-FT80Ggy2i8d:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L400)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
The name setParallel is a bit unexpected naming convention, I'd expect either a bool or numParallelThreads(number) but if this convention is used elsewhere in Moco then would be fine to keep
Done. ___ *[`OpenSim/Common/MultivariatePolynomialFunction.h` line 103 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-Nhbn_WQ7mk0q3fJ2Brx:-NhctpBrA-L-iBjJAv2s:bp2b0y0) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Common/MultivariatePolynomialFunction.h#L103)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
Do you think returning a fresh copy could be a performance bottleneck? Is this exercised during simulation?
I'm returning a temporary `SimTK::Vector` constructed inside this method, so returning it like this should be optimized by the compiler. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4986673/is-it-necessary-to-stdmove-in-a-return-statement-and-should-you-return-rvalue ___ *[`OpenSim/Common/Object.h` line 347 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhY2Qik3VAdhYFXMeqJ:-NhcuX214tYlcnKkxna4:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Common/Object.h#L347)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
For consistency with naming of other methods in the file I'd call this method getPropertyByName. Same for other new methods that do name lookup. Curious why this was needed now
Done. ___ *[`OpenSim/Common/Object.h` line 355 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhY4kqG9w9tftNtTwKh:-Nhcvwk38QsVobhXfsQn:b3mbjjb) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Common/Object.h#L355)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
This looks fine but I'm wondering if this is part of the drive-by changes or are relevant to this PR functionality. Thank you @nickbianco
They are used in `PolynomialPathFitter` and `ModelFactory::replacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths`. ___ *[`OpenSim/Simulation/SimulationUtilities.h` line 401 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhbpZR94k9sS8U0EBzV:-NhcwWIo9DqiqRX6yCJ9:b-ia93di) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Simulation/SimulationUtilities.h#L401)):*
Previously, aymanhab (Ayman Habib) wrote…
Should the method name include "speeds" vs "derivatives"? Trying to consolidate the comment with the naming
Added the "AsSpeeds" suffix for clarity.

pull_request.title: `PolynomialPathFitter` and other utilities for `FunctionBasedPath`
pull_request.body: Fixes issue #3390 ### Brief summary of changes This PR introduces `PolynomialPathFitter`, a new utility class for creating `FunctionBasedPath`s by fitting the coefficients of `MultivariatePolynomialFunction`s to path length and moment arm samples taken from a model with geometry-based paths. Given a model, a table of coordinate values, and a set of (optional) user settings, this class automatically samples path lengths and moment arms from the model based on Latin hypercube sampling and determins the polynomial coefficients using a least-squares fit. In addition to the new class, various other smaller changes are included to make everything work: - Added `ModelFactor::replacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths` and `ModOpReplacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths`. - Added `calcTermValues` and `calcTermDerivatives` to `MultivariatePolynomialFunction`. - Added `Object::getProperty(const std::string& name)` and `Object::updProperty(const std::string& name)`. - Added `TypeHelper`s to `Property` for `SimTK::Vec2` types. - Added `SimulationUtilities::appendCoupledCoordinateValues` and `TabOpAppendCoupledCoordinateValues`. - Added `SimulationUtilities::appendCoordinateValueDerivatives` and `TabOpAppendCoordinateValueDerivatives`. - Minor updates to `FunctionBasedPath`. - Other various minor drive-by fixes that I encountered along the way. ### Testing I've completed Added `testPolynomialPathFitter.cpp`. ### Looking for feedback on... Anything and everything. ### CHANGELOG.md (choose one) - updated. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581)

pull_request.title: Prevent zero-mass bodies and locked coordinates + support `MocoFrameDistanceConstraint` serialization
pull_request.body:
Fixes issue #3542, #3579 

### Brief summary of changes
This PR adds some checks to prevent bugs (e.g., NaNs in CasADi) due to locked coordinates and bodies with zero mass. I also fixed a minor bug preventing serialization of `MocoFrameDistanceConstraint`.

### Testing I've completed
Added tests to `testMocoInterface.cpp` and `testMocoGoals.cpp`.

### Looking for feedback on...

### CHANGELOG.md (choose one)

- updated.

comment.body:
Apologies for the delay on looking at this, but I've been a bit busy, and now I'm away

I'd nominate @pepbos  to have a quick look, given that he's interested in similar ideas etc. and knows his way around C++ 😉

review.body:
> Reviewed 21 of 29 files at r1. > *[Reviewable](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581)* status: 26 of 29 files reviewed, 10 unresolved discussions (waiting on @adamkewley and @nickbianco) *[a discussion](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhXpxVw4HrhIuq3TiGc:-NhXyWdAC2SMzVRFVxY-:blxp5ia) (no related file):*
Previously, nickbianco (Nicholas Bianco) wrote…
1. You can be selective. We save the fitted polynomial paths to an XML file, so you can modify the XML file or load specific paths in to the model with the API. We could also add an `exclude_paths` option on `ModOpReplacePathWithFunctionBasedPaths`. 2. This class will only fit paths that derive from `AbstractPath` and (currently) will throw an exception if the model passed in already has `FunctionBasedPath`s. We could be more granular and only fit paths that are `GeometryPath` (or other future geometry-based paths), but for now I just assume that users do not intend to pass in a model with a `FunctionBasedPath`. 3. By both paths, do you mean supporting both a `GeometryPath` and a `FunctionBasedPath` for the same force object? Then yes that name convention might be confusing. But that could be handled in a future PR I think.
Thanks for the clarification @nickbianco now I can proceed. ___ ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/ModelFactory.cpp` line 318 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhXzZzO0oex9gnpTi0L:-NhXzZzO0oex9gnpTi0M:b-1clfi3) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/ModelFactory.cpp#L318)):* > ```cpp > > // Get the force component associated with this path. > OPENSIM_THROW_IF(!model.hasComponent(path.getName()), > ``` Have you considered using Path or AbstractPath instead of Force? If so we use more specific class in updComponent<> here so we don't end up catching unrelated components? I think there're methods to go from Path to the owner component safely and you're only using Object level methods anyway. ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 46 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhbrrsX-CvPfNnTxd2y:-NhbrrsX-CvPfNnTxd2z:bbnrsns) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L46)):* > ```objc > OpenSim_DECLARE_PROPERTY(coordinate_path, std::string, > "The path to the bounded coordinate in the model.") > OpenSim_DECLARE_PROPERTY(bounds, SimTK::Vec2, > ``` coordinate may not be "bounded" in the model, would it be clearer to say path to the coordinate to be bounded during fitting? ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 80 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-Nhbt4BwAZfTTftYngGg:-Nhbt4BwAZfTTftYngGh:b-5s230q) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L80)):* > ```objc > * `setMomentArmsThreshold` method determines whether or not a path depends on a > * model coordinate. In other words, the moment arm of a path with respect to a > * particular coordinate must be greater than this value to be included during > ``` using absolute value? ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 97 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhbuTfMBiWbqCMulq9z:-NhbuTfMBiWbqCMulqA-:b-bvjjuj) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L97)):* > ```objc > * the Latin hypercube sampling algorithm used to sample coordinate values for > * path fitting. > * > ``` With all these tolerances I'm assuming the model is assumed to be in meters so a model of a small bird or a dinosaur may not work out of the box? Is this something to account for or include a disclaimer? ___ *[`OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h` line 400 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-Nhbta3dB7jbYDgFTgff:-Nhbta3dB7jbYDgFTgfg:b-lhwrr4) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Actuators/PolynomialPathFitter.h#L400)):* > ```objc > void setParallel(int numThreads); > /// @copydoc setParallel() > int getParallel() const; > ``` The name setParallel is a bit unexpected naming convention, I'd expect either a bool or numParallelThreads(number) but if this convention is used elsewhere in Moco then would be fine to keep ___ *[`OpenSim/Common/MultivariatePolynomialFunction.h` line 103 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-Nhbn_WQ7mk0q3fJ2Brx:-Nhbn_WQ7mk0q3fJ2Bry:b7b3jvj) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Common/MultivariatePolynomialFunction.h#L103)):* > ```objc > /// Get a vector of the terms in the polynomial function. > SimTK::Vector getTermValues(const SimTK::Vector& x) const; > /// Get a vector of the derivatives of the terms in the polynomial function. > ``` Do you think returning a fresh copy could be a performance bottleneck? Is this exercised during simulation? ___ *[`OpenSim/Common/Object.h` line 347 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhY2Qik3VAdhYFXMeqJ:-NhY2Qik3VAdhYFXMeqK:b9q49z5) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Common/Object.h#L347)):* > ```objc > template const Property& > getProperty(const std::string& name) const; > ``` For consistency with naming of other methods in the file I'd call this method getPropertyByName. Same for other new methods that do name lookup. Curious why this was needed now ___ *[`OpenSim/Common/Object.h` line 355 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhY4kqG9w9tftNtTwKh:-NhY4kqG9w9tftNtTwKi:b-a2kh3x) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Common/Object.h#L355)):* > ```objc > /** @copydoc updProperty(const PropertyIndex&) **/ > template Property& > updProperty(const std::string& name); > ``` This looks fine but I'm wondering if this is part of the drive-by changes or are relevant to this PR functionality. Thank you @nickbianco ___ *[`OpenSim/Simulation/SimulationUtilities.h` line 401 at r1](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581#-NhbpZR94k9sS8U0EBzV:-NhbpZR94k9sS8U0EBzW:bsrbj4x) ([raw file](https://github.com/opensim-org/opensim-core/blob/2e4b7e5d964d28b99b0bd516707775c3723378f1/OpenSim/Simulation/SimulationUtilities.h#L401)):* > ```objc > TimeSeriesTable& table, const Model& model, > bool overwriteExistingColumns = true); > ``` Should the method name include "speeds" vs "derivatives"? Trying to consolidate the comment with the naming

pull_request.title: `PolynomialPathFitter` and other utilities for `FunctionBasedPath`
pull_request.body: Fixes issue #3390 ### Brief summary of changes This PR introduces `PolynomialPathFitter`, a new utility class for creating `FunctionBasedPath`s by fitting the coefficients of `MultivariatePolynomialFunction`s to path length and moment arm samples taken from a model with geometry-based paths. Given a model, a table of coordinate values, and a set of (optional) user settings, this class automatically samples path lengths and moment arms from the model based on Latin hypercube sampling and determins the polynomial coefficients using a least-squares fit. In addition to the new class, various other smaller changes are included to make everything work: - Added `ModelFactor::replacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths` and `ModOpReplacePathsWithFunctionBasedPaths`. - Added `calcTermValues` and `calcTermDerivatives` to `MultivariatePolynomialFunction`. - Added `Object::getProperty(const std::string& name)` and `Object::updProperty(const std::string& name)`. - Added `TypeHelper`s to `Property` for `SimTK::Vec2` types. - Added `SimulationUtilities::appendCoupledCoordinateValues` and `TabOpAppendCoupledCoordinateValues`. - Added `SimulationUtilities::appendCoordinateValueDerivatives` and `TabOpAppendCoordinateValueDerivatives`. - Minor updates to `FunctionBasedPath`. - Other various minor drive-by fixes that I encountered along the way. ### Testing I've completed Added `testPolynomialPathFitter.cpp`. ### Looking for feedback on... Anything and everything. ### CHANGELOG.md (choose one) - updated. - - - This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/opensim-org/opensim-core/3581)

issue.title: Run time error when trying to visualize the sim
issue.body:
Ubuntu 22.04, Python 3.9.15, and opensim 4.4.

I am getting the following errors when I set the visualize=True, it runs when I set the visualize=False.
- `RuntimeError: std::exception in 'SimTK::State & OpenSim::Model::initSystem()': SimTK Exception thrown at VisualizerProtocol.cpp:162:`
  - /home/aurelien/anaconda3/envs/opensim/simbody/libexec/simbody/Final system error was errno=2 (No such file or directory).
  (Required condition 'status == 0' was not met.)
- `RuntimeError: std::exception in 'SimTK::State & OpenSim::Model::initSystem()': std::exception` 

These are the steps I took to create my conda environment

1. conda create -n opensim python=3.9
2. conda activate opensim
3. conda install -c opensim-org opensim=4.4=py39np120

Am I missing an install step to be able to visualize the sim?

comment.body: Apologies, @mrrezaie, I didn't read the previous comments carefully. It looks like the release was build with Python 3.8. Thank you for testing!

issue.title: export model to gltf as a python utility
[Feature Request] Expose getCoordinatesInMultibodyTreeOrder() for Python/MATLAB users
issue.body:
Hi, I'm trying to get the coordinates in multibody tree order (not CoordinateSet order), but I get this Swig object which means [getCoordinatesInMultibodyTreeOrder()](https://simtk.org/api_docs/opensim/api_docs/classOpenSim_1_1Model.html#a31ba542fd1461f1533bd0813adbeec39) is not exposed yet.
`<Swig Object of type 'std::vector< SimTK::ReferencePtr< OpenSim::Coordinate const >,std::allocator< SimTK::ReferencePtr< OpenSim::Coordinate const > > > *' at 0x000001B5680FB300>`
And sometimes it prints:
`swig/python detected a memory leak of type 'std::vector< SimTK::ReferencePtr< OpenSim::Coordinate const >,std::allocator< SimTK::ReferencePtr< OpenSim::Coordinate 
const > > > *', no destructor found.`

In general, I think it would be great if OpenSim uses same order in all its tools. For example, the InverseDynamics tool uses multibody tree order, whereas InverseKinematics, BodyKinematics, RRA output, and etc. use CoordinateSet order.
